revisions.rev:
{{Infobox character | name = Ros Myers | series = [[Spooks]] | image = [[File:Ros myers.jpg|250px]] | caption = [[Hermione Norris]] as Ros Myers | first = "[[List of Spooks episodes#ep37|Gas and Oil, Part 1]]" | last = "[[Series 8, Episode 8 (Spooks)|Series 8, Episode 8]]" | portrayer = [[Hermione Norris]] | occupation = [[MI5]] officer | title = Senior Case Officer, Section D (5.2â6.8)
Chief of Section D (7.2â8.8) | family = Sir Jocelyn Myers (father) | nationality = [[English people|English]] }} '''Rosalind "Ros" Sarah Myers''' {{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/spooks/characters/rosmyers.shtml |title=BBC â Spooks â Personnel â Ros Myers |work=BBC.co.uk/spooks |accessdate=5 August 2010}} (1973â2009) was a [[fictional character]] from the [[BBC]] [[espionage]] [[television series]] ''[[Spooks]]'', which follows the exploits of Section D, a [[counter-terrorism]] division in [[MI5]]. She is portrayed by British actress [[Hermione Norris]]. The character was a former [[MI6]] officer who works with MI5 in the fifth series. She was promoted to Chief of Section D in the seventh series. At the end of the eighth series, Ros is killed in a hotel explosion. ==Role in ''Spooks''== Ros Myers was born in the year 1973. She is introduced in the first episode of the fifth series as an [[Secret Intelligence Service|MI6]] officer working under Michael Collingwood. In the same episode, Section D learns that Collingwood is plotting a conspiracy to overrule the [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|Prime Minister]], and launch measures to combat [[terrorism]], at the cost of several [[civil liberties]].{{cite episode |title=[[List of Spooks episodes#ep37|Gas and Oil, Part 1]] |series=[[Spooks]] |credits=Omar Madha (director); [[Ben Richards (writer)|Ben Richards]] (writer) |network=[[BBC]] |station=[[BBC One]] |airdate=17 September 2006 |seriesno=5 |number=1}} In the second episode, Ros learns that her father, Sir Jocylen Myers, is funding the conspiracy, and she persuades him out of it, as the rest of the team stop Collingwood. At the end of the episode, [[Adam Carter]] ([[Rupert Penry-Jones]]) offers her a position in Section D, which she takes.{{cite episode |title=[[List of Spooks episodes#ep38|Gas and Oil, Part 2]] |series=[[Spooks]] |credits=Omar Madha (director); [[Ben Richards (writer)|Ben Richards]] (writer) |network=[[BBC]] |station=[[BBC One]] |airdate=18 September 2006 |seriesno=5 |number=2}} In the fourth episode, she is angered to learn that despite [[Harry Pearce]]'s ([[Peter Firth]]) promise of going easy on her father, he is instead sentenced to 20 years imprisonment.{{cite episode |title=[[List of Spooks episodes#ep40|World Trade]] |series=[[Spooks]] |credits=Kenny Glenaan (director); [[David Farr]] (writer) |network=[[BBC]] |station=[[BBC One]] |airdate=2 October 2006 |seriesno=5 |number=4}} In the first episode of the sixth series, fellow officer [[Zafar Younis]] ([[Raza Jaffrey]]) is kidnapped by [[Mercenary|mercenaries]].{{cite episode |title=[[List of Spooks episodes#ep47|The Virus, Part 1]] |series=[[Spooks]] |credits=Omar Madha (director); [[Neil Cross]] (writer) |network=[[BBC]] |station=[[BBC One]] |airdate=16 October 2007 |seriesno=6 |number=1}} When she hears that French Intelligence have a lead on his whereabouts, Adam gives her 24 hours.{{cite episode |title=[[List of Spooks episodes#ep48|The Virus, Part 2]] |series=[[Spooks]] |credits=Omar Madha (director); [[Neil Cross]] (writer) |network=[[BBC]] |station=[[BBC One]] |airdate=23 October 2007 |seriesno=6 |number=2}} However, it is revealed the lead was a ruse and she is kidnapped by a shadow organisation known as Yalta. They torture her as a way of recruiting her; they also convince her that the [[United States]] [[Federal government of the United States|government]] is manipulating the [[United Kingdom]] during peace deals with [[Iran]].{{cite episode |title=[[List of Spooks episodes#ep49|The Kidnap]] |series=[[Spooks]] |credits=Charles Beeson (director); [[David Farr]] (writer) |network=[[BBC]] |station=[[BBC One]] |airdate=30 October 2007 |seriesno=6 |number=3}} Towards the end of the series, Section D and the [[Central Intelligence Agency|CIA]] are made aware of Yalta.{{cite episode |title=[[List of Spooks episodes#ep53|Broadcast]] |series=[[Spooks]] |credits=Stefan Schwartz (director); [[David Farr]] (writer) |network=[[BBC]] |station=[[BBC One]] |airdate=27 November 2007 |seriesno=6 |number=7}} In the eighth episode, CIA liaison [[Bob Hogan]] ([[Matthew Marsh (actor)|Matthew Marsh]]) begins to systematically kill known members. Ros reveals herself as a member to Section D, but wants to help them in stopping Yalta's plans, which is revealed to be setting off a [[logic bomb]] against the American defense satellite network. Though Adam and [[Malcolm Wynn-Jones]] ([[Hugh Simon]]) stop the attack, one of Yalta's high ranking members, [[Juliet Shaw]] ([[Anna Chancellor]]) supposedly kills Ros for her betrayal by injecting her with poison. During her funeral however, Adam revives her and reveals he switched the poison with a sedative to fake her death beforehand. In the end of the episode, Ros walks away with a new identity to protect herself from further Yalta retribution.{{cite episode |title=[[List of Spooks episodes#ep54|Infiltration]] |series=[[Spooks]] |credits=Stefan Schwartz (director); [[Neil Cross]] (writer) |network=[[BBC]] |station=[[BBC One]] |airdate=4 December 2007 |seriesno=6 |number=8}} In the seventh series, which takes place six months after series six, Ros is revealed to be working in [[Moscow]] as "Range Finder", to bring intelligence back to [[London]] which reveals a planned attack during a [[Remembrance Day]] ceremony. Adam finds a car rigged to explode and drives it to an unpopulated zone, but dies as he exits the exploding car.{{cite episode |title=[[List of Spooks episodes#ep57|New Allegiances]] |series=[[Spooks]] |credits=Colm McCarthy (director); [[Neil Cross]] & [[Ben Richards (writer)|Ben Richards]] (writers) |network=[[BBC]] |station=[[BBC One]] |airdate=27 October 2008 |seriesno=7 |number=1}} In the next episode, Harry promotes Ros to succeed Adam as Chief of Section D.{{cite episode |title=[[List of Spooks episodes#ep58|Split Loyalties]] |series=[[Spooks]] |credits=Colm McCarthy (director); [[Neil Cross]] & [[Ben Richards (writer)|Ben Richards]] (writers) |network=[[BBC]] |station=[[BBC One]] |airdate=28 October 2008 |seriesno=7 |number=2}} In later episodes of the series, Ros works to uncover an [[Federal Security Service (Russia)|FSB]] mole within the section, who is attempting to sabotage "Sugar Horse", a top secret MI5 operation involving the recruitment of [[Russia]]ns into top [[Government of Russia|government]] positions, and therefore, become aware of Russia's intentions towards the United Kingdom.{{cite episode |title=[[List of Spooks episodes#ep62|Accidental Discovery]] |series=[[Spooks]] |credits=[[Edward Hall (director)|Edward Hall]] (director); [[David Farr]] (writer) |network=[[BBC]] |station=[[BBC One]] |airdate=24 November 2008 |seriesno=7 |number=6}} Ros and the team later discover the mole is [[Connie James]] ([[Gemma Jones]]), and she is arrested.{{cite episode |title=[[List of Spooks episodes#ep63|The Mole]] |series=[[Spooks]] |credits=[[Sam Miller]] (director); [[James Moran]] & Christian Spurrier (writers) |network=[[BBC]] |station=[[BBC One]] |airdate=1 December 2008 |seriesno=7 |number=7}} However, in the finale, she and [[Lucas North]] ([[Richard Armitage (actor)|Richard Armitage]]) are forced to use her help when they discover "Tiresius", Russia's equivalent of Sugar Horse, has planted a nuclear bomb in London. After finding the bomb, Connie disarms it, but dies in the process.{{cite episode |title=[[List of Spooks episodes#ep64|Nuclear Strike]] |series=[[Spooks]] |credits=[[Sam Miller]] (director); [[Neil Cross]] (writer) |network=[[BBC]] |station=[[BBC One]] |airdate=8 December 2008 |seriesno=7 |number=8}} In episode three of the eighth series, following a [[hostage situation]], Ros kills a terrorist before he can detonate a bomb. However, because [[Jo Portman]] ([[Miranda Raison]]) held on to the terrorist, the bullet passed through him and entered her chest, killing Jo as well.{{cite episode |title=[[List of Spooks episodes#ep67|Episode 3]] |series=[[Spooks]] |credits=[[Sam Miller]] (director); Christian Spurrier & Sean Reilly (writers) |network=[[BBC]] |station=[[BBC One]] |airdate=18 November 2009 |seriesno=8 |number=3}} Ros has since been affected by it.{{cite episode |title=[[Series 8, Episode 4 (Spooks)|Episode 4]] |series=[[Spooks]] |credits=[[Sam Miller]] (director); [[David Farr]] (writer) |network=[[BBC]] |station=[[BBC One]] |airdate=25 November 2009 |seriesno=8 |number=4}}{{cite episode |title=[[List of Spooks episodes#ep70|Episode 6]] |series=[[Spooks]] |credits=[[Edward Hall (director)|Edward Hall]] (director); [[Dennis Kelly]] (writer) |network=[[BBC]] |station=[[BBC One]] |airdate=9 December 2009 |seriesno=8 |number=6}} In the fifth episode, she is contacted by Jack Colville, her recruiter into MI6. Later in the episode, Colville finds a way to hack into MI5's records through Ros; account to kill every officer responsible for the death of Mina, his love in [[Bosnia and Herzegovina|Bosnia]] several years before. To stop Colville, Ros has her name planted as the one who ordered Mina's death. Jack pursues Ros and, as he is about to kill her, she reveals the truth. Realizing that it was not the agents, but the system that was wrong, he kills himself.{{cite episode |title=[[List of Spooks episodes#ep69|Episode 5]] |series=[[Spooks]] |credits=Alrick Riley (director); Richard McBrien (writer) |network=[[BBC]] |station=[[BBC One]] |airdate=2 December 2009 |seriesno=8 |number=5}} In the [[Series 8, Episode 8 (Spooks)|series finale]], a multinational shadow organisation, Nightingale, attempts to cause a [[Nuclear warfare|nuclear war]] between [[India]] and [[Pakistan]]. To put a stop to it, Ros and Lucas attempt to rescue a paralysed [[President of Pakistan|Pakistani President]] Mudasser and [[Home Secretary]] [[Andrew Lawrence (Spooks)|Andrew Lawrence]] ([[Tobias Menzies]]) from a hotel rigged to explode. As Lucas rescues Mudasser, Ros struggles to pull Lawrence to safety, and is still inside as the hotel explodes, resulting in their deaths.{{cite episode |title=[[Series 8, Episode 8 (Spooks)|Episode 8]] |series=[[Spooks]] |credits=Alrick Riley (director); [[Ben Richards (writer)|Ben Richards]] (writer) |network=[[BBC]] |station=[[BBC One]] |airdate=23 December 2009 |seriesno=8 |number=8}} In the first episode of the ninth series it is revealed that former Home Secretary [[Nicholas Blake (Spooks)|Nicholas Blake]] ordered the bombing; in revenge, Harry travels to his home in [[Scotland]] and kills him by poisoning his [[whisky]].{{cite episode |title=[[List of Spooks episodes#ep73|Episode 1]] |series=[[Spooks]] |credits=Paul Whittington (director); Jonathan Brackley & Sam Vincent (writers) |network=[[BBC]] |station=[[BBC One]] |airdate=20 September 2010 |seriesno=9 |number=1}} She was succeeded as Chief of Section D by [[Lucas North]] who had previously served as Chief of Section D in the late 90s before [[Tom Quinn (Spooks)|Tom Quinn]] == Reception == The character has been well-received by critics; ''[[The Guardian|Guardian]]'' journalist Gareth McLean wrote during the broadcast of ''Spooks''{{'}} seventh series that "Not only is Ros Myers the best character that Spooks has ever had [...] she's also the best female character currently on television."McLean, Gareth (3 November 2008). "[http://www.guardian.co.uk/culture/garethmcleanblog/2008/nov/03/spooks-ros-myers-hermione-norris Spooks' Ros Myers is the best female character on TV. Fact]". guardian.co.uk (Guardian News & Media). Retrieved on 26 December 2009. On the website of ''[[The Stage]]'', Scott Matthewman concurred with McLean, writing, "She is indeed one of the hottest female characters on television at the moment."Matthewman, Scott (6 November 2008). "[http://blogs.thestage.co.uk/tvtoday/2008/11/is-ros-myers-the-best-spook-ever/ Is Ros Myers the best Spook ever?]". The Stage Online. Retrieved on 26 December 2009. For her part in the series, Hermione Norris won the Best Actress award at the inaugural [[Crime Thriller Awards]] in 2008.Rosser, Michael, (6 October 2008), "[http://www.broadcastnow.co.uk/news/2008/10/morse_author_honoured_at_crime_thriller_awards.html Morse author honoured at Crime Thriller Awards]". Broadcastnow (Emap Media). Retrieved on 7 October 2008. She was nominated in the same category the next year.Allen, Kate (7 September 2009) "[http://www.thebookseller.com/news/96297-coben-cole-atkinson-vie-for-crime-awards.html Coben, Cole, Atkinson vie for crime awards]". ''The Bookseller''. Retrieved on 7 September 2009. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.bbc.co.uk/spooks/characters/rosmyers.shtml Ros Myers] at [[BBC|BBC.co.uk]] *{{IMDB character|0117607|Ros Myers}} {{Spooks}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Myers, Ros}} [[Category:Fictional characters introduced in 2006]] [[Category:Fictional English people]] [[Category:Fictional members of secret societies]] [[Category:Fictional MI6 agents]] [[Category:Fictional people from London]] [[Category:Fictional secret agents and spies]] [[Category:Spooks characters]] [[es:Ros Myers]]
